review.title: How to correctly prune tropical trees
review.abstract: We present tropical games, a generalization of combinatorial min-max games based on tropical algebras. Our model breaks the traditional symmetry of rational zero-sum games where players have exactly opposed goals (min vs. max), is more widely applicable than min-max and also supports a form of pruning, despite it being less effective than alpha-beta. Actually, min-max games may be seen as particular cases where both the game and its dual are tropical: when the dual of a tropical game is also tropical, the power of alpha-beta is completely recovered. We formally develop the model and prove that the tropical pruning strategy is correct, then conclude by showing how the problem of approximated parsing can be modeled as a tropical game, profiting from pruning.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: We are all familiar with games such as chess or checkers. Such games are purely rational, as they do not involve an element of chance; they are also zero sums, because the interests of the players are two-fold: what "wins," the other loses - which is the origin of the Min-Max rating mechanism. The two basic questions asked in a rational game are "Who will win?" and "How much will she win?." Answering such questions involves searching for a strategy through a (typically large) game tree. Some optimized search techniques have been developed that, in the case of combinatorial two-player games, include the formal circumcision technique [1,2]. α-β is not an approximate algorithm: its correctness is based on the reciprocal distribution properties of Min and Max. In this work, we examine the implications of the assumption that only one player is rational and break the symmetry of traditional "double-sided" rationality.

sections.text: The Alpha-β algorithm [1,2] is a method for calculating the exact value of a minimum and maximum player; < β > β > β > β > β > β > β > combination game without exhaustively visiting all game positions. The Alpha-β algorithm is traditionally presented as a recursive function written in the imperative style (see Figure 1): The Alpha-Beta function analyzes a game position π P with two additional parameters, alpha and β, each of which denotes a kind of threshold that must not be exceeded during the incremental calculation of the value of P. Whenever the threshold exceeds the valuation of an entire sub-tree, it is aborted because it can be proven that it does not contribute to the result.The correctness of Alpha-β is based on the algebraic properties of the minimum and maximum functions, especially their mutual laws of distribution - something we cannot count on among our weaker hypotheses.

sections.heading: 5 Choose-How-To-Divide and Conquer
sections.text: According to the classical technique of Divide and Conquer, a problem can be divided into partial problems, each of which is solved recursively until a minimum instance is found; partial solutions are then reassembled. In the traditional style of Divide and Conquer, one works with non-deterministic decisions in a solution space, using a quality criterion that can be optimized and not reversed. In contrast, we present an alternative model based on tropical games. In the style of Choose-How-To-Divide and Conquer, we work with non-deterministic decisions in a solution space, using a quality criterion that needs to be optimized and "combining" a way. Of course, many non-deterministic algorithms can be expressed in this way: the challenge is to find a suitable match to the tropical game concepts, both in terms of syntax and semantics (with the required properties).

sections.heading: 6 Conclusions and future work
sections.text: As a practical example of the technique, we have shown how the problem of approximate analysis and error localization can be modelled as a game, and how our editing technique can dramatically improve its efficiency; nevertheless, an asymptotic measurement of the number of nodes visited would be a worthwhile development. We suspect that many more problems can be formalized as tropical games, and the problem of analysis itself can definitely be addressed in a more general way by removing our grammar limitations; tropical analyses could prove to be particularly suitable for natural language problems with their inherent ambiguities; the accuracy and efficiency of parallel tropical implementations of α circumcisions would be of particular interest to the study.It is well known that Christophe Fouqueré first recognized tropical algebras in the properties required by our formalization.
